events.title: Launch of the iPad
events.description: Apple launched the iPad, creating a new category of mobile devices.
events.detailed_description: On April 3, 2010, Apple launched the iPad, a tablet computer that introduced a new category of mobile devices. The iPad featured a 9.7-inch touchscreen display, Wi-Fi connectivity, and access to Apple's App Store, revolutionizing how consumers interacted with technology and media.

events.title: Stuxnet Discovery
events.description: Stuxnet, the first known cyber weapon, was discovered.
events.detailed_description: In June 2010, cybersecurity experts discovered Stuxnet, a highly sophisticated computer worm. Believed to be a joint effort by the United States and Israel, Stuxnet was designed to target Iran's nuclear facilities by disrupting centrifuges used for uranium enrichment. This marked the first known instance of a cyber weapon designed to cause physical damage, highlighting the growing threat of cyber warfare.

events.title: Adobe Flash Vulnerabilities
events.description: Multiple security vulnerabilities were discovered in Adobe Flash, leading to its decline.
events.detailed_description: In 2010, numerous security vulnerabilities were discovered in Adobe Flash, prompting widespread criticism and concerns about its safety. These vulnerabilities allowed attackers to exploit systems through web browsers, leading to a decline in Flash's popularity and the gradual shift towards more secure technologies like HTML5.

events.title: WikiLeaks' Afghan War Diary Release
events.description: WikiLeaks released the Afghan War Diary, a collection of U.S. military documents about the War in Afghanistan.
events.detailed_description: On July 25, 2010, WikiLeaks released the Afghan War Diary, a collection of over 75,000 classified U.S. military documents covering the War in Afghanistan from 2004 to 2010. The leak, provided by U.S. Army intelligence analyst Chelsea Manning, exposed detailed accounts of the war, including civilian casualties and the involvement of Pakistani intelligence in insurgent activities. This event raised significant questions about military transparency and national security.

events.title: Facebook Reaches 500 Million Users
events.description: Facebook announced that it had reached 500 million active users worldwide.
events.detailed_description: On July 21, 2010, Facebook announced that it had surpassed 500 million active users, cementing its position as the leading social networking platform. This milestone highlighted Facebook's rapid growth and its influence on global communication and social interaction, setting the stage for its future expansion.

events.title: Launch of Google+
events.description: Google launched Google+, its new social networking platform, to compete with Facebook.
events.detailed_description: On June 28, 2011, Google launched Google+, a social networking service designed to compete with Facebook by offering features like Circles, Hangouts, and Streams. Despite initial hype and rapid user growth, Google+ struggled to sustain user engagement over the years.

events.title: Arab Spring
events.description: A series of pro-democracy uprisings erupted across the Arab world, leading to significant political changes.
events.detailed_description: Beginning in December 2010 and continuing through 2011, the Arab Spring saw widespread protests and uprisings across the Middle East and North Africa. These movements led to the overthrow of governments in Tunisia, Egypt, Libya, and Yemen and sparked ongoing conflicts in Syria and other nations.

events.title: Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Disaster
events.description: A massive earthquake and tsunami led to a nuclear meltdown at the Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant in Japan.
events.detailed_description: On March 11, 2011, a magnitude 9.0 earthquake and subsequent tsunami struck Japan, causing catastrophic damage to the Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant. The disaster led to the meltdown of three reactors, releasing radioactive materials into the environment and forcing the evacuation of hundreds of thousands of residents.

events.title: Osama bin Laden Killed
events.description: Osama bin Laden, the leader of al-Qaeda, was killed in a U.S. Navy SEALs raid in Pakistan.
events.detailed_description: On May 2, 2011, U.S. Navy SEALs conducted a raid on a compound in Abbottabad, Pakistan, resulting in the death of Osama bin Laden. The operation marked a significant milestone in the global fight against terrorism, bringing an end to the decade-long manhunt for the mastermind behind the September 11 attacks.

events.title: Steve Jobs Resigns as Apple CEO
events.description: Steve Jobs stepped down as CEO of Apple due to health issues, marking the end of an era for the company.
events.detailed_description: On August 24, 2011, Steve Jobs resigned as CEO of Apple, citing health concerns. Jobs, who co-founded Apple and was instrumental in its resurgence, handed over the reins to Tim Cook. His resignation marked a significant turning point for Apple, as Jobs had been a visionary leader known for groundbreaking products like the iPhone, iPad, and MacBook.

events.title: Launch of Windows 8
events.description: Microsoft released Windows 8, featuring a major redesign of the user interface.
events.detailed_description: On October 26, 2012, Microsoft released Windows 8, introducing a new user interface centered around the Start screen and Live Tiles, optimized for touch devices. The release marked a significant shift from the traditional Windows desktop interface and was designed to unify the user experience across PCs, tablets, and smartphones.

events.title: Facebook IPO
events.description: Facebook held its initial public offering (IPO), becoming one of the largest technology IPOs in history.
events.detailed_description: On May 18, 2012, Facebook went public with its initial public offering (IPO) on the NASDAQ stock exchange. Priced at $38 per share, the IPO raised $16 billion, valuing the company at over $100 billion. The event marked a significant milestone in Facebook's growth and the tech industry, despite initial trading glitches and subsequent stock price volatility.

events.title: Discovery of Higgs Boson
events.description: Physicists at CERN confirmed the discovery of the Higgs boson, a fundamental particle in physics.
events.detailed_description: On July 4, 2012, scientists at CERN announced the discovery of a new particle consistent with the Higgs boson, a key element in the Standard Model of particle physics. The discovery, made using the Large Hadron Collider (LHC), provided crucial evidence for the mechanism that gives mass to elementary particles, confirming a theory proposed by physicist Peter Higgs in 1964.

events.title: Launch of Raspberry Pi
events.description: The Raspberry Pi Foundation launched the Raspberry Pi, a low-cost, credit-card-sized computer.
events.detailed_description: On February 29, 2012, the Raspberry Pi Foundation released the Raspberry Pi Model B, a low-cost, credit-card-sized computer designed to promote computer science education and hobbyist projects. Priced at around $35, the Raspberry Pi quickly gained popularity for its affordability and versatility, becoming a staple in education and DIY electronics.

events.title: Gangnam Style Goes Viral
events.description: Psy's 'Gangnam Style' music video went viral, becoming the first YouTube video to reach 1 billion views.
events.detailed_description: Released on July 15, 2012, South Korean artist Psy's 'Gangnam Style' became a global sensation, characterized by its catchy tune and iconic dance moves. The music video became the first on YouTube to reach 1 billion views by December 21, 2012, highlighting the power of social media and video-sharing platforms in shaping global pop culture.

events.title: Adobe Creative Cloud Launch
events.description: Adobe launched Creative Cloud, a subscription-based service for its software suite.
events.detailed_description: On June 17th, 2013, Adobe officially launched Creative Cloud, transitioning its software suite to a subscription-based model. This marked a significant shift in the software industry, as Adobe moved from perpetual licenses to a cloud-based service, offering users access to the latest updates and features for applications like Photoshop, Illustrator, and Premiere Pro.

events.title: First Release of Slack
events.description: Slack, a team collaboration tool, was released.
events.detailed_description: On August 14th, 2013, Slack was officially released to the public, providing a new platform for team collaboration and communication. Initially developed as an internal tool for the company Tiny Speck during their game development process, Slack quickly gained popularity for its user-friendly interface and integration capabilities, transforming workplace communication.

events.title: Introduction of Docker
events.description: Docker, a platform for containerization, was introduced.
events.detailed_description: Docker was introduced on March 20th, 2013, at PyCon, revolutionizing the way developers build, ship, and run applications. Docker's containerization technology provides a lightweight and portable environment, enabling developers to ensure consistency across multiple environments from development to production, thus improving the software deployment process.

events.title: Edward Snowden NSA Leaks
events.description: Edward Snowden leaked classified information from the NSA, exposing global surveillance programs.
events.detailed_description: In June 2013, former NSA contractor Edward Snowden began leaking classified documents to journalists, revealing the extent of global surveillance programs conducted by the National Security Agency (NSA) and its allies. These leaks sparked worldwide debates on privacy, government surveillance, and the balance between national security and individual rights.

events.title: Bitcoin Price Surge
events.description: Bitcoin's price experienced a significant surge, reaching over $1,000 for the first time.
events.detailed_description: In November 2013, Bitcoin, the decentralized cryptocurrency, reached a price milestone of over $1,000 per Bitcoin. This marked a significant moment in the cryptocurrency market, drawing widespread attention from investors, media, and the general public, and setting the stage for the future of digital currencies.

events.title: Heartbleed Bug
events.description: The Heartbleed bug, a major security vulnerability in the OpenSSL cryptographic software library, was discovered.
events.detailed_description: On April 7th, 2014, a critical security vulnerability known as the Heartbleed bug was disclosed in the OpenSSL cryptographic software library. This vulnerability allowed attackers to read sensitive data from the memory of servers, compromising the security of encrypted communications and affecting millions of websites worldwide.

events.title: Launch of Kubernetes
events.description: Google open-sourced Kubernetes, a container orchestration platform.
events.detailed_description: On June 7th, 2014, Google announced the open-source release of Kubernetes, a powerful container orchestration platform designed to automate the deployment, scaling, and management of containerized applications. Kubernetes has since become a cornerstone of cloud-native infrastructure and a key tool for developers worldwide.

events.title: Introduction of HTML5
events.description: HTML5, the latest version of the HTML standard, was officially released.
events.detailed_description: On October 28th, 2014, the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) officially recommended HTML5 as the latest version of the HTML standard. HTML5 introduced new features and elements to improve web performance, multimedia support, and user experience, marking a significant advancement in web development.

events.title: Alibaba IPO
events.description: Alibaba Group went public on the New York Stock Exchange in the largest IPO in history.
events.detailed_description: On September 19th, 2014, Alibaba Group, the Chinese e-commerce giant, went public on the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) with an initial public offering (IPO) of $25 billion. This event marked the largest IPO in history at the time and highlighted the growing influence of Chinese technology companies on the global stage.

events.title: Rosetta Spacecraft's Comet Landing
events.description: The European Space Agency's Rosetta spacecraft successfully landed on a comet for the first time in history.
events.detailed_description: On November 12th, 2014, the European Space Agency's Rosetta mission achieved a historic milestone by landing the Philae probe on Comet 67P/Churyumov–Gerasimenko. This was the first time a spacecraft had successfully landed on a comet, providing unprecedented insights into the composition and behavior of these celestial bodies.

events.title: Launch of Windows 10
events.description: Microsoft launched Windows 10, which became one of the most widely used operating systems.
events.detailed_description: On July 29th, 2015, Microsoft released Windows 10, introducing a unified platform for PCs, tablets, and smartphones. Key features included the return of the Start Menu, the introduction of the Edge browser, and the virtual assistant Cortana. Windows 10 aimed to address user feedback from Windows 8 and was offered as a free upgrade for existing Windows users, leading to rapid adoption.

events.title: Launch of the Apple Watch
events.description: Apple launched the Apple Watch, entering the wearable technology market.
events.detailed_description: On April 24th, 2015, Apple entered the wearable technology market with the launch of the Apple Watch. The smartwatch featured fitness tracking, customizable watch faces, and integration with the iPhone, including notifications and apps. The Apple Watch aimed to redefine the smartwatch category and expand Apple's ecosystem, becoming a key product in Apple's lineup.

events.title: Volkswagen Emissions Scandal
events.description: Volkswagen was found to have cheated on diesel emissions tests, leading to a major scandal.
events.detailed_description: In September 2015, Volkswagen was revealed to have used software to cheat on diesel emissions tests, affecting 11 million vehicles worldwide. The scandal, known as Dieselgate, led to significant legal and financial repercussions for Volkswagen and sparked a broader discussion on automotive emissions and regulatory compliance.

events.title: Paris Climate Agreement
events.description: The Paris Climate Agreement was adopted, aiming to limit global warming to below 2 degrees Celsius.
events.detailed_description: On December 12th, 2015, nearly 200 countries adopted the Paris Climate Agreement, committing to efforts to limit global warming to well below 2 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels. The agreement marked a historic milestone in international climate diplomacy, setting targets for reducing greenhouse gas emissions and promoting sustainable development.

events.title: SpaceX Falcon 9 Landing
events.description: SpaceX successfully landed its Falcon 9 rocket's first stage, marking a milestone in reusable rocket technology.
events.detailed_description: On December 21st, 2015, SpaceX achieved a historic milestone in spaceflight by successfully landing the first stage of its Falcon 9 rocket back on Earth after launching a payload into orbit. This achievement demonstrated the potential for reusable rocket technology to significantly reduce the cost of space exploration and paved the way for future advancements in space travel.

events.title: Ebola Outbreak in West Africa Declared Over
events.description: The World Health Organization declared the Ebola outbreak in West Africa officially over.
events.detailed_description: On January 14th, 2015, the World Health Organization (WHO) declared the Ebola outbreak in West Africa officially over. The outbreak, which began in 2014, resulted in over 11,000 deaths and had significant social and economic impacts on the affected countries. The end of the outbreak marked a major success in global health efforts and underscored the importance of international cooperation in managing health crises.

events.title: Apple vs. FBI Encryption Dispute
events.description: Apple refused to help the FBI unlock an iPhone, highlighting the debate over privacy and security.
events.detailed_description: On February 16, 2016, a highly publicized legal battle began between Apple and the FBI over access to a locked iPhone belonging to one of the San Bernardino shooters. The FBI requested Apple's assistance in bypassing the phone's encryption, but Apple refused, citing privacy concerns and the potential precedent it could set for weakening security on consumer devices. The case brought significant attention to the balance between national security and individual privacy.

events.title: DDoS Attack on Dyn
events.description: A massive DDoS attack on Dyn disrupted major internet services.
events.detailed_description: On October 21st, 2016, a massive Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attack targeted Dyn, a major Domain Name System (DNS) provider. The attack disrupted internet services across the United States and Europe, affecting popular websites such as Twitter, Spotify, and Reddit. The attack was notable for its use of a botnet composed of Internet of Things (IoT) devices, highlighting the security vulnerabilities of connected devices.

events.title: Yahoo Data Breach
events.description: Yahoo disclosed a data breach affecting over 3 billion accounts.
events.detailed_description: On December 14th, 2016, Yahoo announced that a data breach had affected over 3 billion user accounts, making it the largest known data breach in history. The breach exposed sensitive information, including names, email addresses, and security questions and answers. The incident raised serious concerns about data security and privacy practices, and it impacted Yahoo's acquisition by Verizon.

events.title: Brexit Referendum
events.description: The United Kingdom voted to leave the European Union, leading to significant political and economic changes.
events.detailed_description: On June 23rd, 2016, the United Kingdom held a referendum to decide whether to remain in or leave the European Union. The Leave campaign won with 52% of the vote, initiating a complex and contentious process of withdrawal known as Brexit. The decision led to significant political and economic changes, impacting trade, immigration, and regulatory policies in the UK and the EU.

events.title: US Presidential Election 2016
events.description: Donald Trump was elected as the 45th President of the United States.
events.detailed_description: On November 8th, 2016, Donald Trump won the US presidential election, defeating Democratic candidate Hillary Clinton. Trump's victory was unexpected by many and marked a significant political shift in the United States. The election was notable for its contentious campaign, debates over immigration and trade policies, and discussions around the influence of social media and foreign interference.

events.title: Samsung Galaxy Note 7 Recall
events.description: Samsung issued a global recall for the Galaxy Note 7 due to battery issues causing explosions.
events.detailed_description: In September 2016, Samsung announced a global recall of its Galaxy Note 7 smartphones following reports of battery explosions. The recall affected millions of devices and cost Samsung billions of dollars. The incident damaged Samsung's reputation and highlighted the importance of rigorous product testing and quality control in the consumer electronics industry.

events.title: WannaCry Ransomware Attack
events.description: The WannaCry ransomware attack affected thousands of computers worldwide.
events.detailed_description: On May 12th, 2017, the WannaCry ransomware attack began spreading rapidly across the globe, infecting over 230,000 computers in 150 countries. The attack exploited a vulnerability in Microsoft's Windows operating system, encrypting files and demanding ransom payments in Bitcoin. The National Health Service (NHS) in the UK was particularly affected, leading to canceled appointments and significant disruption to healthcare services. The attack highlighted the importance of regular software updates and robust cybersecurity measures.

events.title: NotPetya Cyberattack
events.description: The NotPetya cyberattack caused widespread disruption across multiple countries.
events.detailed_description: On June 27th, 2017, the NotPetya cyberattack began spreading globally, initially targeting Ukrainian organizations before affecting businesses and government agencies worldwide. Unlike typical ransomware, NotPetya was a wiper malware disguised as ransomware, designed to destroy data. Major companies like Maersk, FedEx, and Merck suffered severe disruptions, with financial losses estimated at billions of dollars. The attack emphasized the need for robust cybersecurity strategies and highlighted the risks of cyber warfare.

events.title: Equifax Data Breach
events.description: Equifax announced a data breach affecting over 147 million people.
events.detailed_description: On September 7th, 2017, Equifax, one of the largest credit reporting agencies in the US, announced a data breach that exposed the personal information of 147 million individuals. The breach included sensitive data such as Social Security numbers, birth dates, and addresses. The incident raised serious concerns about data security practices in the financial industry and led to increased regulatory scrutiny and class-action lawsuits against Equifax.

events.title: Bitcoin Reaches $19,783
events.description: Bitcoin's value soared to $19,783, driven by a surge in interest and investment in cryptocurrencies.
events.detailed_description: In December 2017, Bitcoin's price reached an all-time high of $19,783, fueled by increased interest from institutional investors, media attention, and the launch of Bitcoin futures trading. This marked a significant milestone in the mainstream adoption of cryptocurrencies, although it also sparked concerns about market volatility and regulatory challenges.

events.title: FCC Repeals Net Neutrality
events.description: The Federal Communications Commission (FCC) voted to repeal net neutrality rules in the United States.
events.detailed_description: On December 14th, 2017, the FCC voted to repeal net neutrality regulations that required internet service providers to treat all internet data equally. The decision sparked a heated debate over the future of internet access, with proponents arguing for market-driven solutions and opponents warning of potential impacts on consumer rights and free expression online.

events.title: Apple iPhone X Release
events.description: Apple released the iPhone X, featuring a new design and advanced Face ID technology.
events.detailed_description: On November 3rd, 2017, Apple released the iPhone X, marking a significant redesign in its flagship smartphone line. The iPhone X introduced Face ID, a facial recognition system, and featured an edge-to-edge OLED display, removing the traditional home button. This release represented a major leap in smartphone technology and design, setting a new standard for mobile devices.

events.title: Discovery of Meltdown and Spectre
events.description: Meltdown and Spectre, two critical security vulnerabilities in modern processors, were disclosed.
events.detailed_description: On January 3rd, 2018, security researchers disclosed Meltdown and Spectre, two significant vulnerabilities affecting nearly every modern computer processor. These flaws allowed malicious programs to steal data being processed on computers, including personal information such as passwords and encryption keys. The discovery prompted urgent responses from hardware and software companies to develop patches and mitigations to protect against these vulnerabilities.

events.title: Cambridge Analytica Scandal
events.description: The Cambridge Analytica data scandal revealed the misuse of Facebook data.
events.detailed_description: On March 17th, 2018, reports emerged detailing how Cambridge Analytica, a data analytics firm, improperly accessed the personal data of millions of Facebook users without their consent. The scandal exposed significant privacy and data protection failures at Facebook and led to widespread public outcry, regulatory investigations, and increased scrutiny of data handling practices by tech companies.

events.title: Establishment of the GDPR
events.description: The General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) was implemented in the European Union.
events.detailed_description: On May 25th, 2018, the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) came into effect in the European Union, marking a significant overhaul of data protection laws. The GDPR introduced strict regulations on how companies collect, process, and store personal data, granting individuals greater control over their personal information. The regulation set a new global standard for privacy and data protection.

events.title: Facebook Data Breach
events.description: Facebook disclosed a data breach affecting 50 million users.
events.detailed_description: On September 28th, 2018, Facebook announced a data breach that impacted the personal information of approximately 50 million users. The breach was caused by a vulnerability in Facebook's code that attackers exploited to gain access to user accounts. This incident raised concerns about Facebook's data security practices and its ability to protect user information.

events.title: Microsoft Acquires GitHub
events.description: Microsoft acquired GitHub, a popular code hosting platform.
events.detailed_description: On October 26th, 2018, Microsoft completed its acquisition of GitHub, a leading platform for software development and version control, for $7.5 billion. The acquisition aimed to strengthen Microsoft's position in the developer community and enhance its cloud computing offerings by integrating GitHub's services with Microsoft's Azure platform.

events.title: SpaceX Falcon Heavy Launch
events.description: SpaceX successfully launched the Falcon Heavy, the most powerful operational rocket in the world.
events.detailed_description: On February 6th, 2018, SpaceX launched its Falcon Heavy rocket from Kennedy Space Center in Florida. The rocket carried a Tesla Roadster as its payload, which was sent into orbit around the sun. The launch marked a significant milestone in space exploration, demonstrating SpaceX's capabilities in developing powerful and cost-effective space travel technologies.

events.title: Google AI Duplex Demonstration
events.description: Google demonstrated Duplex, an AI system capable of making natural-sounding phone calls.
events.detailed_description: In May 2018, Google showcased its AI technology, Duplex, at the Google I/O developer conference. Duplex demonstrated the ability to make phone calls and book appointments while sounding remarkably human-like. The demonstration highlighted the potential of AI to automate everyday tasks but also raised ethical questions about transparency and consent.

events.title: Blockchain Technology Gains Momentum
events.description: Blockchain technology gained significant attention as industries explored its potential applications.
events.detailed_description: Throughout 2018, blockchain technology continued to capture the interest of industries worldwide. Beyond its association with cryptocurrencies, blockchain's potential applications in supply chain management, healthcare, and finance were explored, promising to revolutionize how data is stored and transactions are conducted securely and transparently.

events.title: Yellow Vests Protests in France
events.description: The Yellow Vests movement in France protested against economic inequality and rising fuel prices.
events.detailed_description: In November 2018, the Yellow Vests movement (Gilets Jaunes) emerged in France as a grassroots protest against rising fuel taxes and economic inequality. The protests grew into a larger movement challenging President Emmanuel Macron's policies and calling for broader social and economic reforms. The demonstrations often turned violent, leading to clashes with police and drawing international attention to the issues of inequality and social justice in France.

events.title: Notre Dame Cathedral Fire
events.description: A devastating fire broke out at the Notre Dame Cathedral in Paris, causing significant damage to the historic structure.
events.detailed_description: On April 15th, 2019, a massive fire engulfed the Notre Dame Cathedral in Paris, one of France's most iconic landmarks. The blaze caused the roof and spire to collapse and damaged much of the interior. The incident prompted a global outpouring of support and pledges for restoration, highlighting the cultural and historical significance of the cathedral.

events.title: Amazon Rainforest Fires
events.description: Widespread fires in the Amazon rainforest drew international attention and concern over deforestation and environmental policies.
events.detailed_description: In 2019, the Amazon rainforest experienced a significant increase in fires, largely attributed to deforestation and land-clearing practices. The fires sparked global concern over the environmental impact and the role of Brazilian government policies in managing the Amazon. The incident emphasized the importance of the Amazon in global climate stability and biodiversity.

events.title: Hong Kong Protests
events.description: Mass protests erupted in Hong Kong over a proposed extradition bill, leading to widespread demonstrations and clashes with police.
events.detailed_description: In 2019, Hong Kong witnessed massive protests sparked by a proposed extradition bill that would allow criminal suspects to be extradited to mainland China. The protests evolved into a broader pro-democracy movement, demanding greater autonomy and criticizing Beijing's increasing influence. The demonstrations led to significant political and social unrest, drawing international attention.

events.title: Global Climate Strikes
events.description: Millions of people worldwide participated in climate strikes, demanding action on climate change.
events.detailed_description: In 2019, global climate strikes took place, inspired by young climate activist Greta Thunberg. Millions of people across the world joined the strikes to demand urgent action from governments and corporations to address climate change. The strikes highlighted the growing concern about environmental issues and the demand for sustainable policies.

events.title: Boeing 737 MAX Grounding
events.description: The Boeing 737 MAX was grounded worldwide following two fatal crashes.
events.detailed_description: In 2019, aviation authorities globally grounded the Boeing 737 MAX aircraft after two deadly crashes in Indonesia and Ethiopia. Investigations revealed issues with the aircraft's flight control system, leading to heightened scrutiny of Boeing's safety practices and significant impacts on the aviation industry.

events.title: Chilean Protests
events.description: Protests in Chile erupted over social and economic inequality, leading to widespread demonstrations.
events.detailed_description: Starting in October 2019, Chile saw massive protests triggered by a metro fare increase, which quickly expanded to include broader grievances about social inequality, education, healthcare, and pensions. The protests led to violent clashes with security forces and prompted the Chilean government to initiate reforms and propose a new constitution.

events.title: Google Stadia Launch
events.description: Google launched Stadia, a new cloud-based gaming platform.
events.detailed_description: On November 19th, 2019, Google launched Stadia, a cloud-based gaming service that allows users to stream games without the need for a console or powerful PC. Stadia aimed to revolutionize the gaming industry by offering high-quality gaming experiences accessible from any device with an internet connection.

events.title: Lebanon Protests
events.description: Protests erupted across Lebanon over government corruption and economic mismanagement.
events.detailed_description: In October 2019, mass protests broke out in Lebanon, sparked by proposed taxes and economic mismanagement. The protests quickly evolved into a broader movement demanding political reform, transparency, and accountability from the Lebanese government. The demonstrations led to the resignation of Prime Minister Saad Hariri and highlighted Lebanon's deep-rooted political and economic issues.

events.title: Facebook Cryptocurrency Announcement
events.description: Facebook announced Libra, a new cryptocurrency aimed at revolutionizing global finance.
events.detailed_description: In June 2019, Facebook announced plans to launch Libra, a cryptocurrency designed to facilitate global financial transactions and provide banking services to the unbanked. The announcement sparked significant debate and regulatory scrutiny, with concerns over privacy, security, and the potential impact on global financial systems.

events.title: Apple Card Launch
events.description: Apple launched the Apple Card, a new credit card integrated with Apple Pay.
events.detailed_description: In August 2019, Apple introduced the Apple Card, a credit card designed to integrate seamlessly with Apple Pay and offer users a new way to manage their finances. The card, issued by Goldman Sachs, features a sleek design, no fees, and cashback rewards, aiming to disrupt traditional banking and payment methods.

events.title: Huawei Trade Restrictions
events.description: The United States imposed trade restrictions on Huawei, impacting its business operations globally.
events.detailed_description: In 2019, the United States government imposed trade restrictions on Huawei, citing national security concerns. The restrictions banned American companies from doing business with Huawei, severely impacting the Chinese tech giant's global operations and escalating tensions between the US and China in the tech sector.

events.title: Black Lives Matter Movement
events.description: The Black Lives Matter movement gained national and international attention.
events.detailed_description: On February 26, 2012, the Black Lives Matter movement gained prominence after the shooting of Trayvon Martin in Florida. The movement grew significantly in response to several high-profile cases of police brutality against Black individuals in the United States, including the deaths of Michael Brown in 2014 and Freddie Gray in 2015. It calls for an end to systemic racism and police violence against Black communities.

events.title: Sandy Hook Elementary School Shooting
events.description: A gunman killed 26 people at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Connecticut.
events.detailed_description: On December 14, 2012, a tragic mass shooting occurred at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Connecticut. A gunman killed 26 people, including 20 children and six staff members, before taking his own life. The massacre prompted widespread national debate about gun control and mental health policy in the United States.

events.title: Flint Water Crisis
events.description: The water crisis in Flint, Michigan, revealed high levels of lead contamination.
events.detailed_description: In April 2014, the city of Flint, Michigan, switched its water source to the Flint River as a cost-saving measure. The new water supply was not properly treated, leading to severe lead contamination and widespread health issues. The Flint water crisis became a symbol of governmental neglect and environmental racism, sparking nationwide calls for accountability and clean water rights.

events.title: Mars Rover Curiosity Lands on Mars
events.description: NASA's Curiosity rover successfully landed on Mars, beginning a new era of exploration.
events.detailed_description: On August 6, 2012, NASA's Curiosity rover successfully landed on Mars in the Gale Crater, marking a significant achievement in space exploration. Curiosity's mission was to investigate the Martian climate and geology and assess whether Mars ever had the conditions to support microbial life.

events.title: Greta Thunberg Begins Climate Activism
events.description: Greta Thunberg started her school strike for climate change, inspiring a global movement.
events.detailed_description: On August 20, 2018, Greta Thunberg, a Swedish teenager, began her school strike for climate outside the Swedish Parliament, demanding stronger action on climate change. Her solitary protest sparked a global movement, with millions of students participating in climate strikes worldwide, emphasizing the urgency of addressing climate change.
